topics.title: Leadership diagnosis: can’t, won’t, not set up
topics.summary: Anuj shares a leadership framework for why execution fails: capability gaps, motivation/alignment issues, or poor setup/ways of working. He outlines how leaders should respond—coach/mentor, realign incentives/vision, or fix the system they designed.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Anuj Rathi’s background (Flipkart, Walmart Labs, Snapdeal, Swiggy, Jupiter) and previews topics: India product context, onboarding/new users, working backwards, divergent exploration, and full-stack PM thinking.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Sanity (headless CMS for fast content iteration) and Vanta (security compliance automation), followed later by Wix Studio (agency website building platform).

topics.title: How product building differs in India
topics.summary: Anuj explains India’s product-management evolution: limited consumer-product history pre-2010, lack of playbooks, and cross-functional leaders coming from non-software backgrounds. He contrasts predictable “machinery” thinking with the uncertainty of software and consumer behavior.

topics.title: When India’s consumer internet really ramped
topics.summary: They discuss early India internet categories (travel, matrimony) and why 2010 marked the broader startup wave (Flipkart, Ola, later Swiggy). Anuj notes the shift from “X for India” clones to more uniquely innovative India-first products.

topics.title: India’s scale, infrastructure, and complexity
topics.summary: Anuj highlights the Jio internet wave, UPI/India Stack digitization, and the diversity of languages/cultures that breaks many standard product frameworks. He also explains the monetization challenge: massive engagement potential but low willingness/ability to pay, requiring sharper segmentation and pricing strategy.

topics.title: Designing for new users: lazy, vain, selfish
topics.summary: Anuj introduces Scott Belsky’s framing of modern users as lazy, vain, and selfish, and argues onboarding and first impressions often matter more than advanced features. The key is empathizing with users who don’t care yet and building messaging, copy, and flows that quickly show personal value.

topics.title: Applying onboarding insights at Swiggy and Jupiter
topics.summary: He describes connecting acquisition messaging to in-app onboarding (continuity from ad/promo to first session) and investigating triggers for download and past rejection. For multi-product apps like Jupiter, he emphasizes behavioral design to move users from one service to another rather than pitching everything at once.

topics.title: PMs as full-stack influencers (users and teams)
topics.summary: Anuj argues PMs are in the business of influence—internally across stakeholders and externally on user behavior. He stresses choosing a clear positioning, timing cross-sell carefully, and avoiding “here’s the app, go figure it out” product design.

topics.title: Operationalizing Working Backwards with PR/FAQ
topics.summary: Anuj explains working backwards as planning the full go-to-market machine, not just customer value. He uses PR/FAQ to negotiate scope and timelines, surface misalignment via stakeholder quotes, and ensure cross-functional readiness.

topics.title: Power of three: write three divergent PR/FAQs
topics.summary: He pushes teams to draft three fully formed, divergent press releases to explore alternatives, show what was considered, and help leadership compare tradeoffs. This also helps counter top-down directives by offering better options with clear rationale.

topics.title: Using FAQs to manage marketplace complexity
topics.summary: Anuj describes embedding mandatory FAQ sections (compliance at Jupiter; multi-sided impacts at Swiggy) to force teams to consider second-order effects. This creates tighter coordination across marketplace participants and reduces surprises from interconnected changes.

topics.title: Why full-stack PMs win: outcomes over features
topics.summary: He argues PM success requires owning outcomes and understanding competition, marketing, engineering, and adjacent teams—not just a narrow feature area. He cites the ‘Range’ idea: broader experience helps connect dots and build better products.

topics.title: Show don’t tell: person-based journeys and walls
topics.summary: Anuj explains a concrete, narrative approach to product design: model a real ‘person’ (not a persona), map triggers, emotions, and end-to-end flows, and visualize scenarios (including marketplace real-time dynamics). He recommends maintaining current vs. future journey artifacts to drive clarity and stakeholder alignment.

topics.title: Impact of show don’t tell: alignment and decisions
topics.summary: They discuss how concrete artifacts improve cross-functional alignment and help teams choose among strategic alternatives by evaluating the whole system rather than debating isolated points. Anuj ties this to the broader benefit of ‘working backwards’—forcing specificity to reveal weak ideas early.

topics.title: Four BB framework for product strategy allocation
topics.summary: Anuj introduces a portfolio framework for allocating capacity: Brilliant Basics (foundational/platform work), Bread and Butter (incremental backlog), Big Bets (cross-team high-upside initiatives), and Breaking Bad (identity shifts/pivots). He emphasizes these are strategy-level tradeoffs that leadership must explicitly choose and communicate.
